Input-output theory for spin-photon coupling in Si double quantum dots

M. Benito,1 X. Mi,2 J. M. Taylor,3 J. R. Petta,2 and Guido Burkard1 1Department of Physics, University of Konstanz, D-78457 Konstanz, Germany 2Department of Physics, Princeton University, Princeton, New Jersey 08544, USA 3Joint Quantum Institute/NIST, College Park, Maryland 20742, USA
Abstract

The interaction of qubits via microwave frequency photons enables long-distance qubit-qubit coupling and facilitates the realization of a large-scale quantum processor. However, qubits based on electron spins in semiconductor quantum dots have proven challenging to couple to microwave photons. In this theoretical work we show that a sizable coupling for a single electron spin is possible via spin-charge hybridization using a magnetic field gradient in a silicon double quantum dot. Based on parameters already shown in recent experiments, we predict optimal working points to achieve a coherent spin-photon coupling, an essential ingredient for the generation of long-range entanglement. Furthermore, we employ input-output theory to identify observable signatures of spin-photon coupling in the cavity output field, which may provide guidance to the experimental search for strong coupling in such spin-photon systems and opens the way to cavity-based readout of the spin qubit.

pacs:
42.50.Pq, 73.21.La, 03.67.Lx, 85.35.Gv

I Introduction

Building a practical solid state quantum processor necessitates a flexible scheme of coupling individual qubits such that a 2D array of qubits, or even a network with connectivity between arbitrary pairs of qubits (“all-to-all” connectivity), may be achieved Fowler et al. (2012); Córcoles et al. (2015); Debnath et al. (2016). For superconducting qubits, entanglement of qubits separated by macroscopic distances has been demonstrated using the approach of circuit quantum electrodynamics (cQED) Raimond et al. (2001); Blais et al. (2004); Childress et al. (2004); Cottet et al. , whereby photons confined inside microwave frequency cavities serve as mobile carriers of quantum information that mediate long-range qubit interactions Majer et al. (2007); Sillanpaa et al. (2007). Compared to superconducting qubits, qubits based on spins of electrons in semiconductor quantum dots (QDs) have the virtue of long lifetimes (T1subscript𝑇1T_{1}) that can be on the order of seconds for Si Yang et al. (2013); Zwanenburg et al. (2013). On the other hand, the coupling of spin qubits has remained limited by nearest neighbor exchange interactions with typical distances <<100 nm Petta et al. (2005); Veldhorst et al. (2015). The development of a spin-cQED architecture in which spin qubits are coherently coupled to microwave frequency photons is therefore a critical goal which would enable a spin-based quantum processor with full connectivity.

To transfer quantum states between a spin qubit and a cavity photon with high fidelity, it is necessary to achieve the strong-coupling regime in which the spin-photon coupling gssubscript𝑔𝑠g_{s} exceeds both the cavity decay rate κ𝜅\kappa and the spin decoherence rate γssubscript𝛾𝑠\gamma_{s} Raimond et al. (2001); Imamoğlu (2009). While demonstrations of strong coupling have already been made with superconducting qubits Wallraff et al. (2004) and semiconductor charge qubits Mi et al. (2017a); Stockklauser et al. (2017); Bruhat et al. , such a task has proven challenging for a single spin due to its small magnetic dipole, which results in coupling rates that are less than 1 kHz and too slow compared to typical spin dephasing rates Imamoğlu (2009); Amsüss et al. (2011); Bienfait et al. (2016); Eichler et al. (2017). An alternative route toward strong spin-photon coupling involves hybridizing the spin and charge states of QD electrons Childress et al. (2004); Trif et al. (2008); Cottet and Kontos (2010); Hu et al. (2012); Beaudoin et al. (2016). The relatively large electric susceptibilities of the electron charge states lead to an effective spin-photon coupling rate gssubscript𝑔𝑠g_{s} on the order of MHz, as recently demonstrated by a carbon nanotube double quantum dot (DQD) device Viennot et al. (2015). However, spin-charge hybridization also renders spin qubits susceptible to charge noise, which has up to now prevented the strong coupling regime from being reached with a single spin Viennot et al. (2015).

Here we analyze a scheme for strong spin-photon coupling using a semiconductor DQD placed in the inhomogeneous magnetic field of a micromagnet, first outlined in Ref. Hu et al. (2012). We extend this previous work by predicting a complete map of the effective spin-photon coupling rate gssubscript𝑔𝑠g_{s} and spin decoherence rate γssubscript𝛾𝑠\gamma_{s}. This allows us to find optimal working points for coherent spin-photon coupling. We further present detailed calculations of the cavity transmission and identify experimentally observable signatures of spin-photon coupling. Importantly, we predict that the strong-coupling regime between a single spin and a single photon is achievable in Si using values of the charge-cavity vacuum Rabi frequency gcsubscript𝑔𝑐g_{c} and charge decoherence rate γcsubscript𝛾𝑐\gamma_{c} from recent experiments Mi et al. (2017b, a).

The physical system consists of a gate-defined Si DQD that is embedded in a superconducting cavity; see Fig. 1. The electric-dipole interaction couples the electronic charge states in the DQD to the cavity electric field. The introduction of an inhomogeneous magnetic field, as sketched in Fig. 1, hybridizes the charge states of a DQD electron with its spin states, indirectly coupling the cavity electric field to the electron spin.

II The model

We assume that the DQD is filled with a single electron and has two charge configurations, with the electron located either on the left (L) or right (R) dot, with onsite energy difference (detuning) ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon and tunnel coupling tcsubscript𝑡𝑐t_{c}. If a homogeneous magnetic field Bzsubscript𝐵𝑧B_{z} and a perpendicular spatial gradient field Bxsubscript𝐵𝑥B_{x} are applied we can model the single electron DQD with the Hamiltonian

H0=12​(ϵ​τz+2​tc​τx+Bz​σz+Bx​σx​τz),subscript𝐻012italic-ϵsubscript𝜏𝑧2subscript𝑡𝑐subscript𝜏𝑥subscript𝐵𝑧subscript𝜎𝑧subscript𝐵𝑥subscript𝜎𝑥subscript𝜏𝑧H_{0}=\frac{1}{2}\left(\epsilon\tau_{z}+2t_{c}\tau_{x}+B_{z}\sigma_{z}+B_{x}\sigma_{x}\tau_{z}\right), (1)

where ταsubscript𝜏𝛼\tau_{\alpha} and σαsubscript𝜎𝛼\sigma_{\alpha} are the Pauli operators in position (L,R) and spin space, respectively. Here, Bz​(x)subscript𝐵𝑧𝑥B_{z(x)} are the magnetic fields in energy units and ℏ=1Planck-constant-over-2-pi1\hbar=1. This is a 4-level Hamiltonian with eigenenergies Ensubscript𝐸𝑛E_{n} and eigenstates |n⟩ket𝑛\left|n\right\rangle for n=0,..,3n=0,..,3. The eigenenergies in the regime 2​tc>Bz2subscript𝑡𝑐subscript𝐵𝑧2t_{c}>B_{z} (2​tc<Bz2subscript𝑡𝑐subscript𝐵𝑧2t_{c}<B_{z}) are shown in Fig. 2 (a) [Fig. 2 (b)]. The magnetic field gradient generates spin-charge hybridization, coupling the original (Bx=0subscript𝐵𝑥0B_{x}=0) energy levels (dashed lines) and inducing anticrossings at ϵ=±4​tc2+Bz2italic-ϵplus-or-minus4superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑐2superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑧2\epsilon=\pm\sqrt{4t_{c}^{2}+B_{z}^{2}} if 2​tc<Bz2subscript𝑡𝑐subscript𝐵𝑧2t_{c}<B_{z}; see Fig 2 (b).

In the dipole approximation, the coupling of the DQD to the electric field of a microwave cavity can be described as

HI=gc​(a+a†)​τz,subscript𝐻Isubscript𝑔𝑐𝑎superscript𝑎†subscript𝜏𝑧H_{\mathrm{I}}=g_{c}\left(a+a^{\dagger}\right)\tau_{z}\ , (2)

where a𝑎a and a†superscript𝑎†a^{\dagger} are the bosonic cavity photon creation and annihilation operators. The Hamiltonian for the relevant cavity mode, with frequency ωcsubscript𝜔c\omega_{\mathrm{c}} is Hc=ωc​a†​asubscript𝐻csubscript𝜔csuperscript𝑎†𝑎H_{\mathrm{c}}=\omega_{\mathrm{c}}a^{\dagger}a. In the eigenbasis of H0subscript𝐻0H_{0}, the interaction acquires non-diagonal elements,

HI=gc​(a+a†)​∑n,m=03dn​m​|n⟩​⟨m|.subscript𝐻Isubscript𝑔𝑐𝑎superscript𝑎†superscriptsubscript𝑛𝑚03subscript𝑑𝑛𝑚ket𝑛bra𝑚H_{\mathrm{I}}=g_{c}\left(a+a^{\dagger}\right)\sum_{n,m=0}^{3}d_{nm}\left|n\right\rangle\left\langle m\right|\ . (3)

As we will show below, the essential dynamics of this system can also be described in terms of a so called ΛΛ\Lambda-system, with two weakly-coupled excited states and a ground state; see Figs. 2 (c) and (d) Novikov et al. (2015); Kubo (2016); Jamonneau et al. (2016).

III Input-output theory

To treat the DQD and the cavity as an open system, we move into the Heisenberg picture and use the quantum Langevin equations (QLEs) for the system operators, including the photon operators a,a†,𝑎superscript𝑎†a,a^{\dagger}, and σn​m=|n⟩​⟨m|subscript𝜎𝑛𝑚ket𝑛bra𝑚\sigma_{nm}=\left|n\right\rangle\left\langle m\right|. This treatment enables the calculation of the outgoing fields, aout,1subscript𝑎out1a_{\mathrm{out},1} and aout,2subscript𝑎out2a_{\mathrm{out},2}, at the two cavity ports given the incoming weak fields, ain,1subscript𝑎in1a_{\mathrm{in},1} and ain,2subscript𝑎in2a_{\mathrm{in},2} (Collett and Gardiner, 1984; Gardiner and Collett, 1985; Burkard and Petta, 2016).

If the average population of the energy levels, pn≡⟨σn​n⟩subscript𝑝𝑛delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝜎𝑛𝑛p_{n}\equiv\left\langle\sigma_{nn}\right\rangle, follows a thermal distribution, the linear response to a probe field is reflected in the dynamics of the non-diagonal operators σn​msubscript𝜎𝑛𝑚\sigma_{nm}. If the cavity is driven with a microwave field with a near-resonant frequency ωRsubscript𝜔R\omega_{\mathrm{R}}, the QLEs in a frame rotating with the driving frequency read

This formalism allows us to compute the transmission through the microwave cavity. IV Orbital basis

with r=(2​tc−Bz)2+Bx2𝑟superscript2subscript𝑡𝑐subscript𝐵𝑧2superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑥2{r=\sqrt{(2t_{c}-B_{z})^{2}+B_{x}^{2}}} and the spin-orbit mixing angle Φ=arctan⁡Bx2​tc−BzΦsubscript𝐵𝑥2subscript𝑡𝑐subscript𝐵𝑧{\Phi=\arctan{\frac{B_{x}}{2t_{c}-B_{z}}}} (Φ∈(0,π)Φ0𝜋\Phi\in(0,\pi)). As the dipole operator couples the states |−,↓⟩ket↓\left|-,\downarrow\right\rangle and |+,↓⟩ket↓\left|+,\downarrow\right\rangle and the field gradient couples |+,↓⟩ket↓\left|+,\downarrow\right\rangle to |−,↑⟩ket↑\left|-,\uparrow\right\rangle, the combination of these two effects leads to a coupling between the two different spin states |−,↓⟩ket↓\left|-,\downarrow\right\rangle and |−,↑⟩ket↑\left|-,\uparrow\right\rangle. It is this coupling that can be harnessed to coherently hybridize a single electron spin with a single photon and achieve the strong-coupling regime.

V Results

V.1 Effective coupling at zero detuning

The spin-charge hybridization created by the inhomogeneous magnetic field allows for the coupling of the spin to the cavity. This is visible in the form of the operator d𝑑d in the eigenbasis; see Eq. (3). In the simple case of zero DQD detuning, ϵ=0italic-ϵ0\epsilon=0, the ordered energy levels are

E3,0subscript𝐸30\displaystyle E_{3,0} =\displaystyle= ±12​(2​tc+Bz)2+Bx2,plus-or-minus12superscript2subscript𝑡𝑐subscript𝐵𝑧2superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑥2\displaystyle\pm\frac{1}{2}\sqrt{(2t_{c}+B_{z})^{2}+B_{x}^{2}}, (11)
E2,1subscript𝐸21\displaystyle E_{2,1} =\displaystyle= ±12​(2​tc−Bz)2+Bx2.plus-or-minus12superscript2subscript𝑡𝑐subscript𝐵𝑧2superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑥2\displaystyle\pm\frac{1}{2}\sqrt{(2t_{c}-B_{z})^{2}+B_{x}^{2}}. (12)

Using the spin-orbit mixing angle ΦΦ\Phi, the eigenstates |1⟩ket1\left|1\right\rangle and |2⟩ket2\left|2\right\rangle can be expressed as

|1⟩ket1\displaystyle\left|1\right\rangle =\displaystyle= cos⁡Φ2​|−,↑⟩+sin⁡Φ2​|+,↓⟩,Φ2ket↑Φ2ket↓\displaystyle\cos{\frac{\Phi}{2}}\left|-,\uparrow\right\rangle+\sin{\frac{\Phi}{2}}\left|+,\downarrow\right\rangle, (13)

while the other two can be approximated by

|3⟩ket3\displaystyle\left|3\right\rangle ≃similar-to-or-equals\displaystyle\simeq |+,↑⟩,ket↑\displaystyle\left|+,\uparrow\right\rangle, (16)

if r≪(2​tc+Bz)much-less-than𝑟2subscript𝑡𝑐subscript𝐵𝑧r\ll(2t_{c}+B_{z}), i.e., for small |2​tc−Bz|2subscript𝑡𝑐subscript𝐵𝑧|2t_{c}-B_{z}|. In this limit, the dipole matrix elements,

d=(0d01d020d0100d13d0200d230d13d230),𝑑matrix0subscript𝑑01subscript𝑑020subscript𝑑0100subscript𝑑13subscript𝑑0200subscript𝑑230subscript𝑑13subscript𝑑230d=\begin{pmatrix}0&d_{01}&d_{02}&0\\ d_{01}&0&0&d_{13}\\ d_{02}&0&0&d_{23}\\ 0&d_{13}&d_{23}&0\end{pmatrix}, (17)

This means that the hybridization due to the weak magnetic field gradient generates an effective coupling between the levels |−,↓⟩ket↓\left|-,\downarrow\right\rangle and |−,↑⟩ket↑\left|-,\uparrow\right\rangle, with opposite spin. The spin nature of the transitions 0↔1↔010\leftrightarrow 1 and 0↔2↔020\leftrightarrow 2 depends on the spin-orbit mixing angle ΦΦ\Phi; see Eqs. (13) to (15). Assuming that the cavity frequency is tuned to the predominantly spin-like transition, which is 0↔1↔010\leftrightarrow 1 (0↔2↔020\leftrightarrow 2) for cos⁡Φ>0Φ0\cos\Phi>0 (cos⁡Φ<0Φ0\cos\Phi<0), the effective spin-cavity coupling strength will be given by gs=gc​|d01​(2)|subscript𝑔ssubscript𝑔𝑐subscript𝑑012g_{\mathrm{s}}=g_{c}|d_{01(2)}|.

V.2 Effective coupling at ϵ≠0italic-ϵ0\epsilon\neq 0

For ϵ≠0italic-ϵ0\epsilon\neq 0 the energy levels are

E3,0subscript𝐸30\displaystyle E_{3,0} =±12​[(Ω+Bz2+Bx2​sin2⁡θ)2+Bx2​cos2⁡θ]1/2,absentplus-or-minus12superscriptdelimited-[]superscriptΩsuperscriptsubscript𝐵𝑧2superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑥2superscript2𝜃2superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑥2superscript2𝜃12\displaystyle={\pm}\frac{1}{2}\left[\left(\Omega+\sqrt{B_{z}^{2}+B_{x}^{2}\sin^{2}{\theta}}\right)^{2}{+}B_{x}^{2}\cos^{2}{\theta}\right]^{1/2}, (20)

Analogously to the previous section, if (Ω−Bz)2+Bx2≪(Ω+Bz)much-less-thansuperscriptΩsubscript𝐵𝑧2superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑥2Ωsubscript𝐵𝑧\sqrt{(\Omega-B_{z})^{2}+B_{x}^{2}}\ll(\Omega+B_{z}) we can approximate the eigenstates by Eqs. (13) to (16) where the spin-orbit mixing angle is now Φ=arctan⁡Bx​cos⁡θΩ−BzΦsubscript𝐵𝑥𝜃Ωsubscript𝐵𝑧\Phi=\arctan{\frac{B_{x}\cos\theta}{\Omega-B_{z}}} (Φ∈(0,π)Φ0𝜋\Phi\in(0,\pi)). Within this approximation,

d01subscript𝑑01\displaystyle d_{01} =\displaystyle= d23≃−cos⁡θ​sin⁡Φ2,similar-to-or-equalssubscript𝑑23𝜃Φ2\displaystyle d_{23}\simeq-\cos\theta\sin\frac{\Phi}{2}, (22)

V.3 Effective coupling map

Before calculating the effect of the Si DQD on the cavity transmission A𝐴A, let us estimate the magnitude of the coupling gssubscript𝑔sg_{\mathrm{s}}. For Ω>BzΩsubscript𝐵𝑧\Omega>B_{z} (Ω<BzΩsubscript𝐵𝑧\Omega<B_{z}), 0↔1↔010\leftrightarrow 1 (0↔2↔020\leftrightarrow 2) is predominantly a spin transition, therefore we can obtain a map for the effective coupling by using gs=gc​|d01​(2)|subscript𝑔ssubscript𝑔𝑐subscript𝑑012g_{\mathrm{s}}=g_{c}|d_{01(2)}|; see Fig. 3 (a). As the value of ΩΩ\Omega approaches Bzsubscript𝐵𝑧B_{z}, ΦΦ\Phi tends to π/2𝜋2\pi/2 and the coupling is maximized. However, in this regime, due to strong spin-charge hybridization, the charge nature of the transition increases [see Eqs. (13) and (14)] and with it the decoherence rate increases, preventing the system from reaching strong coupling. In the following we show that the ratio of the coupling rate to the total decoherence rate can be optimized by working away from maximal coupling. In particular the strong-coupling regime for the spin can be achieved.

V.4 Cavity transmission

In the following, we consider the DQD to be in its ground state, such that pn=δn,0subscript𝑝𝑛subscript𝛿𝑛0p_{n}=\delta_{n,0} in Eq. (III). If the cavity frequency is close to the Zeeman energy, ωc∼Bzsimilar-tosubscript𝜔csubscript𝐵𝑧\omega_{\mathrm{c}}\sim B_{z}, the transition 0↔3↔030\leftrightarrow 3 is off-resonant and the relevant dynamics is contained in the level structure of Figs. 2 (c) and (d). Moreover, this transition is not coupled to the others since d03=0subscript𝑑030d_{03}=0 and γ03,n​m=δn​0​δm​3subscript𝛾03𝑛𝑚subscript𝛿𝑛0subscript𝛿𝑚3\gamma_{03,nm}=\delta_{n0}\delta_{m3} (see Appendix B). To calculate the cavity response, it is sufficient to solve the QLEs for ⟨a⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑎\left\langle a\right\rangle, ⟨σ01⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝜎01\left\langle\sigma_{01}\right\rangle and ⟨σ02⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝜎02\left\langle\sigma_{02}\right\rangle (in the following we omit the brackets) within the RWA (see Appendix A).

As explained above, the decoherence processes accounted for in Eq. (III) can result in a different decay rate for every transition and can also couple different transitions. As shown in Appendix B, the decoherence superoperator in the basis {σ01,σ02}subscript𝜎01subscript𝜎02\{\sigma_{01},\sigma_{02}\} reads

This is

Bzres=ωc​1−Bx2ωc2−4​tc2,superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑧ressubscript𝜔c1superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑥2superscriptsubscript𝜔c24superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑐2B_{z}^{\mathrm{res}}=\omega_{\mathrm{c}}\sqrt{1-\frac{B_{x}^{2}}{\omega_{\mathrm{c}}^{2}-4t_{c}^{2}}}, (31)

for ϵ=0italic-ϵ0\epsilon=0. In a small region around 2​tc∼ωcsimilar-to2subscript𝑡𝑐subscript𝜔c2t_{c}\sim\omega_{\mathrm{c}} (ωc​(ωc−Bx)<2​tc<ωc​(ωc+Bx)subscript𝜔csubscript𝜔csubscript𝐵𝑥2subscript𝑡𝑐subscript𝜔csubscript𝜔csubscript𝐵𝑥\sqrt{\omega_{\mathrm{c}}(\omega_{\mathrm{c}}-B_{x})}<2t_{c}<\sqrt{\omega_{\mathrm{c}}(\omega_{\mathrm{c}}+B_{x})}), indicated with the vertical lines in Fig. 3 (b), it is not possible to achieve the desired resonance by tuning Bzsubscript𝐵𝑧B_{z}. We observe that in the wings of the peak gs/gc≫γs/γcmuch-greater-thansubscript𝑔ssubscript𝑔csubscript𝛾ssubscript𝛾cg_{\mathrm{s}}/g_{\mathrm{c}}\gg\gamma_{\mathrm{s}}/\gamma_{\mathrm{c}}, which may lead the spin-cavity system to be in the strong-coupling regime even when the charge-cavity system is not (gc<γcsubscript𝑔csubscript𝛾cg_{\mathrm{c}}<\gamma_{\mathrm{c}}). This is visible in the inset, where we show that the ratio gs/(γs2+(κ/2)2)/2subscript𝑔ssuperscriptsubscript𝛾s2superscript𝜅222g_{\mathrm{s}}/\sqrt{(\gamma_{\mathrm{s}}^{2}+(\kappa/2)^{2})/2} exceeds one, signifying the strong-coupling regime (see Appendix C).

According to the level structure, we expect to observe a signature of spin-photon coupling by driving the cavity near resonance (Δ0∼0similar-tosubscriptΔ00\Delta_{0}\sim 0) and swiping the external magnetic field through the cavity frequency. In Fig. 4 we show the calculated transmission through the cavity as a function of the external magnetic field Bzsubscript𝐵𝑧B_{z} and the DQD detuning ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon when the driving frequency matches the cavity frequency. We have chosen κ1=κ2=κ/2subscript𝜅1subscript𝜅2𝜅2\kappa_{1}=\kappa_{2}=\kappa/2. When the cavity frequency is close to the transition energy 0↔1↔010\leftrightarrow 1, the interaction between the electron and the cavity field results in a significantly reduced cavity transmission. Interestingly, close to Bz∼ωcsimilar-tosubscript𝐵𝑧subscript𝜔cB_{z}\sim\omega_{\mathrm{c}} the transmission approaches one due to an interference between the two energy levels. At this point, χ01​d01+χ02​d02≃0similar-to-or-equalssubscript𝜒01subscript𝑑01subscript𝜒02subscript𝑑020\chi_{01}d_{01}+\chi_{02}d_{02}\simeq 0.

In the usual scenario of a two-level system coupled to a photonic cavity, strong coupling results in light-matter hybridization, as evidenced in the observation of vacuum Rabi splitting in the cavity transmission spectrum when the qubit transition frequency matches the cavity frequency. The two vacuum Rabi normal modes are separated by a frequency corresponding to the characteristic rate of the light-matter interaction, and the linewidth of each mode reflects the average decoherence rate of light and matter Thompson et al. (1992). In Fig. 5 (a), we show the absolute value of the transmission, |A|𝐴|A|, as a function of the magnetic field Bzsubscript𝐵𝑧B_{z} and the driving frequency relative to ωcsubscript𝜔c\omega_{\mathrm{c}}, Δ0subscriptΔ0\Delta_{0}, at ϵ=0italic-ϵ0\epsilon=0. The phase gives similar information (not shown). When the driving frequency is near the cavity frequency, Δ0∼0similar-tosubscriptΔ00\Delta_{0}\sim 0, two peaks emerge in the cavity transmission, signifying the strong-coupling regime. In Figs. 5 (b) and (c) we show the horizontal and vertical cuts of this figure at Δ0=0subscriptΔ00\Delta_{0}=0 and Bz=Bzressubscript𝐵𝑧superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑧resB_{z}=B_{z}^{\mathrm{res}}, respectively, where Bzressuperscriptsubscript𝐵𝑧resB_{z}^{\mathrm{res}}, given by Eq. (31), ensures E1−E0=ωcsubscript𝐸1subscript𝐸0subscript𝜔cE_{1}-E_{0}=\omega_{\mathrm{c}}. In Fig. 5 (b) we observe the same interference effect seen in Fig. 4, and in Fig. 5 (c) the vacuum Rabi splitting. As indicated with a red arrow, the effective coupling, related to the separation between the two peaks, corresponds to gs/2​π∼5​MHzsimilar-tosubscript𝑔s2𝜋5MHzg_{\mathrm{s}}/2\pi\sim 5\,\mathrm{MHz} and the parameters under consideration can be readily achieved in Si DQD architectures (Mi et al., 2017b, a).

In the present case, we are dealing with a three-level system, where the spin-photon coupling is mediated by the spin-charge hybridization Childress et al. (2004). The three-level system structure explains not only the interference but also why the width and position of the two resonance peaks in Fig. 5 (c) is slightly asymmetric. As expected, this asymmetry is more apparent as gcsubscript𝑔𝑐g_{c} increases, which is shown in Fig. 6. In section V.6, we reduce the problem to an equivalent two-level system to be able to characterize the spin-photon coupling within the standard formalism utilized for the Jaynes-Cummings model.

V.5 Broadening due to nuclear spins

The estimated value of the spin decoherence rate induced by the spin-charge hybridization is of the order γs/2​π∼1−10​MHzsimilar-tosubscript𝛾s2𝜋110MHz\gamma_{\mathrm{s}}/2\pi\sim 1-10\,\mathrm{MHz}. Another source of decoherence in Si QDs is the effect of the Si29superscriptSi29{}^{29}\mathrm{Si} nuclear spins which surround the electron spin. As their evolution is slow compared to the typical time scale of the electronic processes, the nuclear spins effectively produce a random magnetic field which slightly influences the total magnetic field on the DQD. This small perturbation of the magnetic field, Bztot=Bz+Bznucsuperscriptsubscript𝐵𝑧totsubscript𝐵𝑧superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑧nucB_{z}^{\mathrm{tot}}=B_{z}+B_{z}^{\mathrm{nuc}}, will modify the frequency ωc+Δ0subscript𝜔csubscriptΔ0\omega_{\mathrm{c}}+\Delta_{0} of the two vacuum Rabi normal modes, as can be extracted from Fig. 5 (a). The nuclear magnetic field follows a Gaussian distribution with average zero and standard deviation σnucsuperscript𝜎nuc\sigma^{\mathrm{nuc}}. In this way, a Gaussian profile is superimposed to the Lorentzian profile of the resonances and the final width also depends on σnucsuperscript𝜎nuc\sigma^{\mathrm{nuc}}. At the point with maximum spin-charge hybridization (Ω∼Bzsimilar-toΩsubscript𝐵𝑧\Omega\sim B_{z}), this effect is negligible because the decoherence is dominated by charge decoherence. Away from this point, the two broadening mechanisms have to be combined, resulting in a Voigt profile Olver et al. (2010). The spin dephasing times in natural Si are ∼1​μ​ssimilar-toabsent1𝜇s\sim 1\,\mu\mathrm{s}, which corresponds approximately to a standard deviation of σnuc/2​π∼0.3​MHzsimilar-tosuperscript𝜎nuc2𝜋0.3MHz\sigma^{\mathrm{nuc}}/2\pi\sim 0.3\,\mathrm{MHz} for the nuclear magnetic field distribution Kawakami et al. (2014). According to Eq. (30), the positions of the two vacuum Rabi modes are given by the solutions of the equation

−Δ0+gc​Re​(χ01​d01+χ02​d02)=0,subscriptΔ0subscript𝑔cResubscript𝜒01subscript𝑑01subscript𝜒02subscript𝑑020-\Delta_{0}+g_{\mathrm{c}}\,\mathrm{Re}\left(\chi_{01}d_{01}+\chi_{02}d_{02}\right)=0, (32)

where the susceptibilities are a function of Δ0subscriptΔ0\Delta_{0} via the detunings δ1​(2)≡E1​(2)−E0−ωRsubscript𝛿12subscript𝐸12subscript𝐸0subscript𝜔R\delta_{1(2)}\equiv E_{1(2)}-E_{0}-\omega_{\mathrm{R}} and ωR=ωc+Δ0subscript𝜔𝑅subscript𝜔csubscriptΔ0\omega_{R}=\omega_{\mathrm{c}}+\Delta_{0}. As the magnetic field created by the nuclear spins is small, we can expand the solutions Δ0±superscriptsubscriptΔ0plus-or-minus\Delta_{0}^{\pm} to first order to obtain

Δ0±≃Δ0±​(Bznuc=0)+∂Δ0±∂Bz|Bznuc=0​Bznuc.similar-to-or-equalssuperscriptsubscriptΔ0plus-or-minussuperscriptsubscriptΔ0plus-or-minussuperscriptsubscript𝐵𝑧nuc0evaluated-atsuperscriptsubscriptΔ0plus-or-minussubscript𝐵𝑧superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑧nuc0superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑧nuc\Delta_{0}^{\pm}\simeq\Delta_{0}^{\pm}(B_{z}^{\mathrm{nuc}}=0)+\left.\frac{\partial\Delta_{0}^{\pm}}{\partial B_{z}}\right|_{B_{z}^{\mathrm{nuc}}=0}B_{z}^{\mathrm{nuc}}. (33)

Therefore the broadening of the vacuum Rabi modes due to the nuclear spins is given by σ=|∂Δ0±/∂Bz|​σnuc𝜎superscriptsubscriptΔ0plus-or-minussubscript𝐵𝑧superscript𝜎nuc\sigma=\left|\partial\Delta_{0}^{\pm}/\partial B_{z}\right|\sigma^{\mathrm{nuc}}, and the total spin decoherence rate is

γstot=γs/2+(γs/2)2+8​(ln⁡2)​σ2.superscriptsubscript𝛾stotsubscript𝛾s2superscriptsubscript𝛾s2282superscript𝜎2\gamma_{\mathrm{s}}^{\mathrm{tot}}=\gamma_{\mathrm{s}}/2+\sqrt{(\gamma_{\mathrm{s}}/2)^{2}+8(\ln{2})\sigma^{2}}. (34)

The long spin dephasing times in Si allow the strong-coupling regime to be reached approximately at the same working points. For instance, for a tunnel coupling tc∼15​μ​eVsimilar-tosubscript𝑡𝑐15𝜇eVt_{c}\sim 15\,\mu\mathrm{eV}, the estimated spin dephasing rate induced by charge hybridization is γs/2​π∼2​MHzsimilar-tosubscript𝛾s2𝜋2MHz\gamma_{\mathrm{s}}/2\pi\sim 2\,\mathrm{MHz} and the broadening due to the nuclear spins is given by σ/2​π∼0.14​MHzsimilar-to𝜎2𝜋0.14MHz\sigma/2\pi\sim 0.14\,\mathrm{MHz}, therefore γstot/2​π∼2​MHzsimilar-tosuperscriptsubscript𝛾stot2𝜋2MHz\gamma_{\mathrm{s}}^{\mathrm{tot}}/2\pi\sim 2\,\mathrm{MHz}.

V.6 Two-level equivalent system

To reduce the problem to a two-level system, it is more convenient to work in the orbital basis. Using the relations in Eqs. (58) and (59) we can rewrite the QLEs in terms of the operators a𝑎a, στ=|−,↓⟩⟨+,↓|\sigma_{\tau}=\left|-,\downarrow\right\rangle\left\langle+,\downarrow\right| and σs=|−,↓⟩⟨−,↑|\sigma_{s}=\left|-,\downarrow\right\rangle\left\langle-,\uparrow\right|. Neglecting input noise terms for the charge relaxation which will be irrelevant for our linear response theory, these equations read

a˙˙𝑎\displaystyle\dot{a} =\displaystyle= i​Δ0​a−κ2​a+κ1​ain,1+i​gc​cos⁡θ​στ,𝑖subscriptΔ0𝑎𝜅2𝑎subscript𝜅1subscript𝑎in1𝑖subscript𝑔𝑐𝜃subscript𝜎𝜏\displaystyle i\Delta_{0}a-\frac{\kappa}{2}a+\sqrt{\kappa_{1}}a_{\mathrm{in},1}+ig_{c}\cos{\theta}\sigma_{\tau}, (35)
σ˙τsubscript˙𝜎𝜏\displaystyle\dot{\sigma}_{\tau} =\displaystyle= −i​Δτ​στ−γc​στ+i​gc​cos⁡θ​a𝑖subscriptΔ𝜏subscript𝜎𝜏subscript𝛾𝑐subscript𝜎𝜏𝑖subscript𝑔𝑐𝜃𝑎\displaystyle-i\Delta_{\tau}\sigma_{\tau}-\gamma_{c}\sigma_{\tau}+ig_{c}\cos{\theta}a\ (36)
+i​Bx​cos⁡θ2​σs,𝑖subscript𝐵𝑥𝜃2subscript𝜎𝑠\displaystyle+i\frac{B_{x}\cos{\theta}}{2}\sigma_{s},
σ˙ssubscript˙𝜎𝑠\displaystyle\dot{\sigma}_{s} =\displaystyle= −i​Δs​σs+i​Bx​cos⁡θ2​στ,𝑖subscriptΔssubscript𝜎𝑠𝑖subscript𝐵𝑥𝜃2subscript𝜎𝜏\displaystyle-i\Delta_{\mathrm{s}}\sigma_{s}+i\frac{B_{x}\cos{\theta}}{2}\sigma_{\tau}, (37)

where Δτ​(s)=±Ω−Bz2−E0−ωRsubscriptΔ𝜏splus-or-minusΩsubscript𝐵𝑧2subscript𝐸0subscript𝜔R\Delta_{\tau(\mathrm{s})}=\pm\frac{\Omega-B_{z}}{2}-E_{0}-\omega_{\mathrm{R}}. As evident from these equations, although the electric field of the cavity only couples to the charge excitation, the spin-charge hybridization generates an effective spin-photon coupling.

Solving equation Eq. (36) for the steady state we can obtain the bright (B) mode that mediates this coupling,

σB=sin⁡α​σs+cos⁡α​a,subscript𝜎𝐵𝛼subscript𝜎𝑠𝛼𝑎\sigma_{B}=\sin\alpha\,\sigma_{s}+\cos{\alpha}\,a\ , (38)

where we have introduced the angle α=arctan⁡Bx2​gc𝛼subscript𝐵𝑥2subscript𝑔c\alpha=\arctan\frac{B_{x}}{2g_{\mathrm{c}}}. For the Eqs. (35) and (37), we obtain the reduced dynamics

According to the derivation in Appendix C, the resonance condition reads

(Δs+Δ0)res=−Δτ​η​2​γc​η+κ​cos⁡2​ακ+2​γc​η​cos⁡2​α,superscriptsubscriptΔ𝑠subscriptΔ0ressubscriptΔ𝜏𝜂2subscript𝛾c𝜂𝜅2𝛼𝜅2subscript𝛾c𝜂2𝛼(\Delta_{s}+\Delta_{0})^{\mathrm{res}}=-\Delta_{\tau}\eta\frac{2\gamma_{\mathrm{c}}\eta+\kappa\cos{2\alpha}}{\kappa+2\gamma_{\mathrm{c}}\eta\cos{2\alpha}}\ , (44)

and strong coupling is achieved for

gs>Γ≡|κ+2​γc​η​cos⁡2​α|2​2​4​γc2​η2+4​γc​η​κ​cos⁡2​α+κ24​γc2​η2+4​γc​η​κ​cos2⁡α+κ2,subscript𝑔sΓ𝜅2subscript𝛾c𝜂2𝛼224superscriptsubscript𝛾c2superscript𝜂24subscript𝛾c𝜂𝜅2𝛼superscript𝜅24superscriptsubscript𝛾c2superscript𝜂24subscript𝛾c𝜂𝜅superscript2𝛼superscript𝜅2g_{\mathrm{s}}>\Gamma\equiv\frac{|\kappa+2\gamma_{\mathrm{c}}\eta\cos{2\alpha}|}{2\sqrt{2}\sqrt{\frac{4\gamma_{\mathrm{c}}^{2}\eta^{2}+4\gamma_{\mathrm{c}}\eta\kappa\cos{2\alpha}+\kappa^{2}}{4\gamma_{\mathrm{c}}^{2}\eta^{2}+4\gamma_{\mathrm{c}}\eta\kappa\cos^{2}{\alpha}+\kappa^{2}}}}, (45)

where we have defined

gs=|Δτ|​η​sin⁡α​cos⁡α=|Δτ|​Bx​gc​cos2⁡θ2​(Δτ2+γc2).subscript𝑔ssubscriptΔ𝜏𝜂𝛼𝛼subscriptΔ𝜏subscript𝐵𝑥subscript𝑔csuperscript2𝜃2superscriptsubscriptΔ𝜏2superscriptsubscript𝛾c2g_{\mathrm{s}}=|\Delta_{\tau}|\eta\sin\alpha\cos\alpha=|\Delta_{\tau}|\frac{B_{x}g_{\mathrm{c}}\cos^{2}{\theta}}{2(\Delta_{\tau}^{2}+\gamma_{\mathrm{c}}^{2})}. (46)

In Fig. 7 we provide a map of the coupling strength via the quantity gs/Γsubscript𝑔sΓg_{\mathrm{s}}/\Gamma, with the magnetic field adjusted to the resonance condition. This map indicates the optimum working points that create a strong spin-photon interaction that overcomes the decoherence.

VI Conclusions

In conclusion, we detail the conditions for achieving strong coupling between a single electron spin and a microwave cavity photon, which eventually would allow long distance spin-spin coupling and long-range spin-qubit gates. Non-local quantum gates may also facilitate quantum error correction within a fault-tolerant architecture, and have already been used for this purpose in other systems Taylor et al. (2005); Reed et al. (2012); Waldherr et al. (2014).

Our analysis on the dynamics of the full hybrid silicon-cQED system confirms that, with the recent advances in Si DQDs fabrication and control, a spin-photon coupling of more than 10​MHz10MHz10\,\mathrm{MHz} with a sufficiently low spin decoherence rate is achievable with this setup, potentially allowing the strong-coupling regime Zajac et al. (2016); Mi et al. (2017a). In such a regime, the cavity not only can act as a mediator of spin-spin coupling but also enables cavity-based readout of the spin qubit state Kawakami et al. (2014); Takeda et al. (2016). Interestingly, the strong-coupling regime for the spin-cavity coupling may be attained even when the coupling strength of the charge-cavity coupling can not overcome the charge decoherence rate.

Although here we have focused on the coupling of a single electron spin to a single photon, the implementation of proposals for other type of spin qubits with more than one electron Burkard and Imamoglu (2006); Jin et al. (2012); Taylor et al. (2013); Russ and Burkard (2015) seems feasible with the present technology in Si QDs.

Appendix B Decoherence model

We assume that the charge relaxation processes dominate over direct spin relaxation. For the coupling to the phonon environment, the Liouvillian superoperator contains charge relaxation (γ1subscript𝛾1\gamma_{1}) and pure dephasing (γϕsubscript𝛾italic-ϕ\gamma_{\phi}),

ℒph​ρsubscriptℒph𝜌\displaystyle\mathcal{L}_{\text{ph}}\rho =\displaystyle= γ12​(2​σ−​ρ​σ+−σ+​σ−​ρ−ρ​σ+​σ−)subscript𝛾122subscript𝜎𝜌subscript𝜎subscript𝜎subscript𝜎𝜌𝜌subscript𝜎subscript𝜎\displaystyle\frac{\gamma_{1}}{2}\left(2\sigma_{-}\rho\sigma_{+}-\sigma_{+}\sigma_{-}\rho-\rho\sigma_{+}\sigma_{-}\right) (51)
+\displaystyle+ γϕ4​(2​σz​ρ​σz−σz​σz​ρ−ρ​σz​σz),subscript𝛾italic-ϕ42subscript𝜎𝑧𝜌subscript𝜎𝑧subscript𝜎𝑧subscript𝜎𝑧𝜌𝜌subscript𝜎𝑧subscript𝜎𝑧\displaystyle\frac{\gamma_{\phi}}{4}\left(2\sigma_{z}\rho\sigma_{z}-\sigma_{z}\sigma_{z}\rho-\rho\sigma_{z}\sigma_{z}\right),

where σ±=|±⟩⟨∓|\sigma_{\pm}=\left|\pm\right\rangle\left\langle\mp\right|, σz=|+⟩⟨+|−|−⟩⟨−|\sigma_{z}=\left|+\right\rangle\left\langle+\right|-\left|-\right\rangle\left\langle-\right|. (Note that in this appendix the Pauli operators σαsubscript𝜎𝛼\sigma_{\alpha} are in the basis of bonding and antibonding states, |±⟩ketplus-or-minus\left|\pm\right\rangle, instead of left and right.)

The interaction Hamiltonian for charge decays can be written as

Hph=∑𝐤c𝐤(|+⟩⟨−|b𝐤+|−⟩⟨+|b𝐤†),H_{\mathrm{ph}}=\sum_{\mathbf{k}}c_{\mathbf{k}}\left(|+\rangle\langle-|b_{\mathbf{k}}+|-\rangle\langle+|b_{\mathbf{k}}^{\dagger}\right), (52)

where bksubscript𝑏𝑘b_{k} annihilates a phonon in mode 𝐤𝐤{\mathbf{k}}. Therefore the relaxation rate at zero temperature can be obtained using Fermi’s Golden Rule,

γ1=2​πℏ​∑f|⟨f​|⟨−|Hph|+⟩|​0⟩|2​δ​(Ω−Ef),subscript𝛾12𝜋Planck-constant-over-2-pisubscript𝑓superscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑓delimited-⟨⟩limit-fromsubscript𝐻ph02𝛿Ωsubscript𝐸𝑓\gamma_{1}=\frac{2\pi}{\hbar}\sum_{f}|\langle f|\langle-|H_{\mathrm{ph}}|+\rangle|0\rangle|^{2}\delta(\Omega-E_{f}), (53)

where |0⟩ket0|0\rangle and |f⟩ket𝑓|f\rangle are the initial phonon vacuum and single-phonon final states, ΩΩ\Omega is the orbital energy (Ω=ϵ2+4​tc2Ωsuperscriptitalic-ϵ24superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑐2\Omega=\sqrt{\epsilon^{2}+4t_{c}^{2}}), and Efsubscript𝐸𝑓E_{f} denotes the phonon energy. Substituting Eq. (52) into Eq. (53), we obtain

γ1=2​πℏ​∑𝐤|c𝐤|2​δ​(Ω−Ek)=2​πℏ​|ck|2​D​(Ω),subscript𝛾12𝜋Planck-constant-over-2-pisubscript𝐤superscriptsubscript𝑐𝐤2𝛿Ωsubscript𝐸𝑘2𝜋Planck-constant-over-2-pisuperscriptsubscript𝑐𝑘2𝐷Ω\gamma_{1}=\frac{2\pi}{\hbar}\sum_{\mathbf{k}}|c_{\mathbf{k}}|^{2}\delta(\Omega-E_{k})=\frac{2\pi}{\hbar}|c_{k}|^{2}D(\Omega), (54)

where k𝑘k is the modulus of the 𝐤𝐤{\mathbf{k}} vector evaluated at the energy ΩΩ\Omega. Here, D​(E)𝐷𝐸D(E) is the phonon density of states. In general, γ1subscript𝛾1\gamma_{1} depends on the parameters tcsubscript𝑡𝑐t_{c} and ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon both via D​(Ω)𝐷ΩD(\Omega) and cksubscript𝑐𝑘c_{k}, since k=k​(Ω)𝑘𝑘Ωk=k(\Omega). We assume here a constant γ1subscript𝛾1\gamma_{1} since we expect that this approximation will hold in a small transition energy window around the cavity frequency.

The pure dephasing term is due to charge noise or fluctuations in the value of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. The main contribution to the dephasing rate γϕsubscript𝛾italic-ϕ\gamma_{\phi} is proportional to the first derivative of the energy transition with respect to ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, i.e.,

γϕ∝∂(E+−E−)∂ϵ=sin⁡θ,proportional-tosubscript𝛾italic-ϕsubscript𝐸subscript𝐸italic-ϵ𝜃\gamma_{\phi}\propto\frac{\partial(E_{+}-E_{-})}{\partial\epsilon}=\sin{\theta}, (55)

therefore is zero at the “sweet spot” ϵ=0italic-ϵ0\epsilon=0.

Using the Liouvillian in Eq. (51), we can calculate the decoherence dynamics for the mean value of any operator as ⟨A˙⟩=tr​{A​ℒph​ρ}delimited-⟨⟩˙𝐴tr𝐴subscriptℒph𝜌\left\langle\dot{A}\right\rangle=\mathrm{tr}\{A\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{ph}}\rho\}. (In the following we omit the brackets for simplicity.) The coherences decay as

σ˙±=−γc​σ±=−(γ12+γϕ)​σ±.subscript˙𝜎plus-or-minussubscript𝛾csubscript𝜎plus-or-minussubscript𝛾12subscript𝛾italic-ϕsubscript𝜎plus-or-minus\dot{\sigma}_{\pm}=-\gamma_{\mathrm{c}}\sigma_{\pm}=-\left(\frac{\gamma_{1}}{2}+\gamma_{\phi}\right)\sigma_{\pm}. (56)

In this work we include the spin degree of freedom and here, we assume spin-independent rates. In the main text we have defined στ=|−,↓⟩⟨+,↓|\sigma_{\tau}=\left|-,\downarrow\rangle\langle+,\downarrow\right| and σs=|−,↓⟩⟨−,↑|\sigma_{s}=\left|-,\downarrow\rangle\langle-,\uparrow\right|. While στsubscript𝜎𝜏\sigma_{\tau} decays as σ˙τ=−γc​στsubscript˙𝜎𝜏subscript𝛾𝑐subscript𝜎𝜏\dot{\sigma}_{\tau}=-\gamma_{c}\sigma_{\tau}, the same type of calculation taking into account the spin reveals σ˙s=0subscript˙𝜎𝑠0\dot{\sigma}_{s}=0. The decoherence part of the dynamics entering in Eq. (III) is obtained via a rotation of the previous uncoupled equations into the eigenbasis of H0subscript𝐻0H_{0}, which results in

σ˙n​m=−∑n′,m′γn​m,n′​m′​σn′​m′.subscript˙𝜎𝑛𝑚subscriptsuperscript𝑛′superscript𝑚′subscript𝛾𝑛𝑚superscript𝑛′superscript𝑚′subscript𝜎superscript𝑛′superscript𝑚′\dot{\sigma}_{nm}=-\sum_{n^{\prime},m^{\prime}}\gamma_{nm,n^{\prime}m^{\prime}}\sigma_{n^{\prime}m^{\prime}}. (57)

From the form of the eigenstates in the bonding-antibonding basis (Eqs. (13) to (16)), we can determine the effect of charge dephasing in the eigenbasis of H0subscript𝐻0H_{0}. Since

σ01subscript𝜎01\displaystyle\sigma_{01} ≃cos⁡Φ2​σs+sin⁡Φ2​στ,similar-to-or-equalsabsentΦ2subscript𝜎𝑠Φ2subscript𝜎𝜏\displaystyle\simeq\cos{\frac{\Phi}{2}}\sigma_{s}+\sin{\frac{\Phi}{2}}\sigma_{\tau}, (58)

the decoherence dynamics can be expressed as

(σ˙01σ˙02)≃−γc​(sin2⁡Φ2−sin⁡Φ2−sin⁡Φ2cos2⁡Φ2)​(σ01σ02).similar-to-or-equalsmatrixsubscript˙𝜎01subscript˙𝜎02subscript𝛾𝑐matrixsuperscript2Φ2Φ2Φ2superscript2Φ2matrixsubscript𝜎01subscript𝜎02\displaystyle\begin{pmatrix}\dot{\sigma}_{01}\\ \dot{\sigma}_{02}\end{pmatrix}\simeq-\gamma_{c}\begin{pmatrix}\sin^{2}\frac{\Phi}{2}&-\frac{\sin{\Phi}}{2}\\ -\frac{\sin{\Phi}}{2}&\cos^{2}\frac{\Phi}{2}\end{pmatrix}\begin{pmatrix}\sigma_{01}\\ \sigma_{02}\end{pmatrix}. (60)

Note also that σ03≃|−,↓⟩⟨+,↑|\sigma_{03}\simeq\left|-,\downarrow\rangle\langle+,\uparrow\right|, therefore its decoherence is decoupled from the rest, σ˙03≃−(γ1+γϕ)​σ03/2similar-to-or-equalssubscript˙𝜎03subscript𝛾1subscript𝛾italic-ϕsubscript𝜎032\dot{\sigma}_{03}\simeq-(\gamma_{1}+\gamma_{\phi})\sigma_{03}/2.

Appendix C Characterization of the spin-photon coupling

In this appendix, we detail the calculation of the strong-coupling condition for our two-level equivalent system. To examine this, we describe the spin-cavity interaction (Eqs. (39) and (40)) with an effective Hamiltonian in the one-excitation manifold. This means that the Hilbert space is composed of states with a single excitation from the ground state, i.e., {|↓,n+1⟩,|↑,n⟩}ket↓𝑛1ket↑𝑛\left\{\left|\downarrow,n+1\right\rangle,\left|\uparrow,n\right\rangle\right\}, where n𝑛n is the number of photons in the cavity. In this basis, the effective Hamiltonian reads

Heffsubscript𝐻eff\displaystyle H_{\mathrm{eff}} =\displaystyle= −(Δ0+i​κ′/200−Δs+i​γs)matrixsubscriptΔ0𝑖superscript𝜅′200subscriptΔs𝑖subscript𝛾s\displaystyle-\begin{pmatrix}\Delta_{0}+i\kappa^{\prime}/2&0\\ 0&-\Delta_{\mathrm{s}}+i\gamma_{\mathrm{s}}\end{pmatrix}
−η​(Δτ​cos2⁡α(Δτ+i​γc)​sin⁡α​cos⁡α(Δτ+i​γc)​sin⁡α​cos⁡αΔτ​sin2⁡α).𝜂matrixsubscriptΔ𝜏superscript2𝛼subscriptΔ𝜏𝑖subscript𝛾c𝛼𝛼subscriptΔ𝜏𝑖subscript𝛾c𝛼𝛼subscriptΔ𝜏superscript2𝛼\displaystyle-\eta\begin{pmatrix}\Delta_{\tau}\cos^{2}\alpha&(\Delta_{\tau}+i\gamma_{\mathrm{c}})\sin\alpha\cos\alpha\\ (\Delta_{\tau}+i\gamma_{\mathrm{c}})\sin\alpha\cos\alpha&\Delta_{\tau}\sin^{2}\alpha\end{pmatrix}.

We note that the eigenvalues of Heffsubscript𝐻effH_{\mathrm{eff}} are of the form

μ±=A−i​B/2±C+i​D,subscript𝜇plus-or-minusplus-or-minus𝐴𝑖𝐵2𝐶𝑖𝐷\mu_{\pm}=A-iB/2\pm\sqrt{C+iD}, (62)

with A,B,C,D𝐴𝐵𝐶𝐷A,B,C,D all real. A𝐴A can be seen to be the average frequency of the system, while B𝐵B is the average damping. However, the C𝐶C and D𝐷D terms are more subtle. For example, if one does not choose the detunings such that D≠0𝐷0D\neq 0, then the two vacuum Rabi-split peaks will have different linewidths. We also find a modification of the strong-coupling condition.

Let us now consider weak versus strong coupling for this system. For the usual Jaynes-Cummings model, where the two-level system is directly coupled to the cavity field, strong coupling is defined as sufficiently large interaction such that two separate peaks are observable in the photon response (C>B2/4𝐶superscript𝐵24C>B^{2}/4) and such that the system modes are (near) equal combinations of matter and light (C>0,D=0formulae-sequence𝐶0𝐷0C>0,D=0). For the Jaynes-Cummings case, the one-excitation Hamiltonian is

HJCsubscript𝐻JC\displaystyle H_{\mathrm{JC}} =\displaystyle= −(Δ0+i​κ/2gJ​CgJ​C−ΔJ​C+i​γJ​C),matrixsubscriptΔ0𝑖𝜅2subscript𝑔𝐽𝐶subscript𝑔𝐽𝐶subscriptΔ𝐽𝐶𝑖subscript𝛾𝐽𝐶\displaystyle-\begin{pmatrix}\Delta_{0}+i\kappa/2&g_{JC}\\ g_{JC}&-\Delta_{JC}+i\gamma_{JC}\end{pmatrix}, (63)

and we have the combined condition

gJ​C>γJ​C2+(κ/2)22,subscript𝑔𝐽𝐶superscriptsubscript𝛾𝐽𝐶2superscript𝜅222g_{JC}>\sqrt{\frac{\gamma_{JC}^{2}+(\kappa/2)^{2}}{2}}, (64)

which reduces to the usual gJ​C>γJ​C,κ/2subscript𝑔𝐽𝐶subscript𝛾𝐽𝐶𝜅2g_{JC}>\gamma_{JC},\kappa/2 for 2​γJ​C≈κ2subscript𝛾𝐽𝐶𝜅2\gamma_{JC}\approx\kappa.
